theorem.caption: Sum of linear maps is linear

info.caption: Comment: What does this proposition tell us?
info.para: This proposition gives us two strong pieces of information:

li.para: The sum of two linear transformations is again linear
If the linear map L is represented by \Mtrx{A} and T is represented by \Mtrx{B}, then the linear map (L+T) is represented by the sum of the matrices \Mtrx{A} + \Mtrx{B}.

info.para: In short: the sum of two linear maps corresponds to the sum of their representing matrices.

statement.para:
If L,T\from \RNr[n] \longrightarrow \RNr[m] are two linear transformations, then their sum
sumof linear transformationsrepresented by sum of matrices
is again linear. Further, if \Mtrx{A} and \Mtrx{B} are the (m,n)-matrices representing L and T respectively, then \Mtrx{A} + \Mtrx{B} represents L+T.
